Considering these knowledge gaps, the present study aims to characterise the seasonal habitat use of *M. asterias* among sexes on a vertical and horizontal scale. Consequently, the study is structured into two points of focus:

<!-- aims to assess seasonal and sex-related differences in movement patterns of *M. asterias* with two different points of focus:  -->

 1. The presence of *M. asterias* in the Western Scheldt estuary.
  - Hypothesis: Females show higher residency in the area of the PBARN receivers than males.
 2. The vertical movement of *M. asterias* on an annual scale.
  - Hypothesis: The vertical movement differs between seasons for both males and females.
  
  

# Materials and Methods


### Acoustic Detections

Detections were accessed from the ETN database (*https://www.lifewatch.be/etn/*). Tags with only a single detection were omitted from all further analyses. Acoustic detections were visualised on an individual and acoustic receiver station level.
 
It was hypothesised that females display higher residency within the area of the PBARN receivers than males. To test this, the residency index was calculated for each individual, dividing the number of days with a detection by one of the receivers by the estimated battery life of 518 days. Then, the residency index was compared between sexes.

### Data Storage Tags {#sec-mm_dsts}
Depth and temperature logs from the recovered tags were accessed via the
Marine Data Archive (MDA) **create DOI**. <!-- TODO: link URL --> The temperature log
was not included in any analysis. The first week of depth values was
excluded from all analyses to remove potential bias resulting from the
tagging procedure [as suggested by @flavio_2021]. The date of death, used to
calculate the time at liberty for the recovered tags, was visually extracted from plots of the
raw depth series, and marks the date after which only a tidal signal
remains in the depthlog [characterised by cyclically rising and
falling depths within a rough 2 m depth range, @kvale_2006]. 

The analyses described in the following were only performed for tags that logged for $\geq$ 365 days. 
Those will be referred to as *long term DST* in the following, tags logging for less than a year will be
referred to as *short term DST*.
<!-- maybe rephrase: "excluded from all analyses" --> Summary statistics
,i.e., median (since depth did not follow a normal distribution), maximum and 
minimum depth were calculated per date, day and night.
<!-- For all of these calculated summary statistics, the daily change was computed (i.e. * variable~change~ = variable~t~ - variable~t-1~).  -->
For the day/night summaries, sunrise and sunset times were extracted
using the `getSunlightTimes()`-function from the `suncalc`-package [@suncalc].
The illuminated fraction of the moon was extracted using the
`moonAngle()`-function from the `oce` package [@oce]. 

To test the hypothesis about difference in depth use between seasons, start dates of summer and winter as defined by solstices were extracted from the Astronomical Applications Department
of the U.S. Naval Observatory [@USNO_2023] for the years of 2018 and 2019.
Next, the daily median depths for each tag and season (summer/winter) were compared.

<!-- the daily median depth was categorised regarding the season (start dates of summer and winter as defined  -->

A Savitzky-Golay smoothing filter [@press_1990,
filter order *p = 1*, filter length *n = 5*] was applied on all summaries using the
`sgolayfilt()`-function from the `signal`-package [@signal]. This particular
filter smoothes the data but retains spikes in the data better than
other smoothing filters like butterworth or averaging filters [like
rolling mean, @schafer_2011].

To test the hypothesis of focus point 1, the residency indices among sexes was tested for normality (shapiro test, $\alpha$ = 0.05, *p~females~* = `r hyp1_results %>% dplyr::filter(test_aim == "normality_f") %>% dplyr::select(p_val) %>% dplyr::pull() %>% round(digits = 4)`, *p~males~* = `r hyp1_results %>% dplyr::filter(test_aim == "normality_m") %>% dplyr::select(p_val) %>% dplyr::pull() %>% round(digits = 4)`), and the residency indices of the females do not follow a normal distribution. Due to high robustness of Welch's t-test regarding non-normality [@rasch_2004], this method was preferred over its non-parametric counterpart, the Wilcoxon rank-sum test. A one-sided Welch two-sample t-test with unequal variances was conducted ($\alpha$ = 0.05, *p* = `r hyp1_results %>% dplyr::filter(test_aim == "equality_of_means") %>% dplyr::select(p_val) %>% dplyr::pull() %>% round(digits = 4)`), showing that the residency index of females is significantly higher than the residency index of males.


## Data Storage Tags {#sec-results-dst}

**(...)**


6 out of 8 recovered tags logged for a month or less, only the tags with
the serial numbers 1293308 (f) and 1293321 (m) logged for a year,
allowing for the analysis of migration behaviour. These two tags will be
referred to as long term DST in the following, and their tag serial
numbers will be abbreviated to `308` and `321`. The rest of the tags
will be referred to as short term DST. 

To test the hypothesis of focus point 2, the daily median depth was used, since the `stats::t.test()`-function does not allow samples larger than n = 3000. The daily median depth per season (summer/winter) and tag were tested for normality (Kolmogorov-Smirnoff-test;  *p~tag308,summer~* = `r ks_results_hyp2.2 %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::filter(tag_serial_number == "1293308", big_season == "summer") %>% dplyr::select(ks_test_pval) %>% pull()`, *p~tag308,winter~* = `r ks_results_hyp2.2 %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::filter(tag_serial_number == "1293308", big_season == "winter") %>% dplyr::select(ks_test_pval) %>% pull()`, *p~tag321,summer~* = `r ks_results_hyp2.2 %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::filter(tag_serial_number == "1293321", big_season == "summer") %>% dplyr::select(ks_test_pval) %>% pull()`, *p~tag321,winter~* = `r ks_results_hyp2.2 %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::filter(tag_serial_number == "1293321", big_season == "winter") %>% dplyr::select(ks_test_pval) %>% pull()`). A Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction shows a significant difference in daily median depth between summer and winter for both tags (*p~308~* = `r hypothesis2.2_testresults %>% dplyr::filter(tag_serial_number == "1293308") %>% dplyr::select(wilcox.test_pval) %>% pull()`, *p~321~* = `r hypothesis2.2_testresults %>% dplyr::filter(tag_serial_number == "1293321") %>% dplyr::select(wilcox.test_pval) %>% pull()`).
